title: Before 1 January 2018, will the U.S. President sign legislation increasing the number of autonomous vehicle exemptions allowed by the Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards?
possible_answers: Yes, but to less than 100,000 exemptions per manufacturer per year
Yes, to 100,000 or more exemptions per manufacturer per year

AV START (S. 1885) allows for up to 100,00 vehicle exemptions after 5 years: "‘‘(iii) during any 12-month period following the period described in clause (ii), the exemption is for not more than 100,000 vehicles to be sold or introduced into interstate commerce in the United States.
‘‘(C) A manufacturer of a highly automated vehicle may petition the Secretary to expand the exemption under paragraph (2)(B) to more than 100,000 vehicles in any 12-month period after the exemption has been in place for 5 years.’’ The House's SELF DRIVE act (HR 3388), which has already passed, says: "LIMITATION ON NUMBER OF VEHICLES EXEMPTED.—All exemptions granted to a manufacturer under subsections (b)(3)(B)(i) through (v) shall not exceed a total of (i) 25,000 vehicles manufactured within the first 12-month period, (ii) 50,000 vehicles manufactured within the second 12-month period, (iii) 100,000 vehicles manufactured within the third 12-month period, and, (iv) 100,000 vehicles manufactured within the fourth 12-month period. Any renewals under subsections (b)(3)(B)(i) through (v) shall not exceed a total of 100,000 vehicles manufactured within a 12-month period.” It looks like Senate has eight more weeks to get this thing through, then President has to sign it. This issue has momentum right now, so I don't see why that shouldn't happen. It's in committee now.

Senate marks up bil S. 1885:  The exemptions could apply to the manufacturing of up to 50,000 autonomous vehicles in the first year, 75,000 vehicles in the second year and 100,000 vehicles in the third year after passage of the bill.
“Self-driving vehicles will make transformative changes to improve mobility, reduce accidents and enhance safety for millions of travelers on our roads,”

The Senate is considering a similar draft measure, but is divided over whether to include large commercial trucks, a dispute that could prevent the bill from winning approval this year. The House measure, which only applies to vehicles under 10,000 pounds (4,536 kg), would allow automakers to obtain exemptions to deploy up to 25,000 vehicles without meeting existing auto safety standards in the first year.

The Gartner Consumer Trends in Automotive online survey, conducted from April 2017 through May 2017, and polled 1,519 people in the U.S. and Germany, found that 55 percent of respondents will not consider riding in a fully autonomous vehicle, while 71 percent may consider riding in a partially autonomous vehicle.
Concerns around technology failures and security are key reasons why many consumers are cautious about fully autonomous vehicles.
"Fear of autonomous vehicles getting confused by unexpected situations, safety concerns around equipment and system failures and vehicle and system security are top concerns around using fully autonomous vehicles," explains Mike Ramsey, research director at Gartner.

The technology for fully autonomous vehicles is not yet there. Despite the fanfare, I believe the US government will move slowly in testing & adoption of such cars/trucks. Regardless of any safety concerns, the current government has so much on its legislative agenda that I believe this bill will not receive much attention before January 1, 2018. Furthermore, a recent NYT article suggests that several auto manufacturers are moving towards a shared model approach because driverless vehicles may not be as profitable as initially thought. Sharing costs and technology will reduce the number of participants (Tesla, Uber, Lyft-Waymo, Daimler-BMW-Audi-Bosch, Honda) and number of test vehicles. https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2017/08/08/business/08reuters-autos-autonomous-bmw.html

I believe that such legislation is highly likely to be enacted before Jan 1, 2020, but unlikely to reach the President's desk prior to Jan 1, 2018.  I would also caveat that such legislation will not happen unless it is being lobbied, (and probably even ghost-written), by representatives of the three major US automotive manufacturers.
it seems like something we would jump into before we are ready so why not.
This is mostly about a fairly paralyzed legislative process in Congress.

While this has made it out of Committee, it still has a long road to go. The House Rules Committee will decide whether this makes the legislative agenda over the coming weeks and months. The House leadership could decide to push it to the floor regardless of the Rules Committee, but they have bigger issues to tackle. Once it goes to the floor, there's no guarantee that it would pass.  Assuming it does pass, it will have to go before the Senate, which has it's own issues to work through. As this is new legislation, it will be subject to a filibuster, and while the language itself is not overly controversial, the Dems (or Reps) could filibuster in an attempt to extract concessions from the other side.  Since it's very unlikely that a House bill makes it through the Senate unmodified, the Senate version will have to go back to the House. If the House doesn't agree with the Senate version, they'll have to send it to conference to work out the issues. Once a conference version comes out, it goes back to each chamber for a floor vote. Assuming it passes in both chambers, then Trump can sign it.  It's a deliberately slow process with a lot of opportunities for the bill to die. Given that Congress has several major pieces of legislation that have to matriculate through this process or through other equally complex processes, it seems unlikely that this floats to the top of the priority list. I'll adjust pending it being scheduled for a floor vote, although passage would be a better indicator of its survival through the process.

There were 11 fatalities  per billion vehicle miles travelled VMT in 2011, . This has declined since then, but it shows how many autonomous vehicles we need to determine their relative safety compared to driver vehicles.  There is a pressing need to have large fleets out there to gather data for policy for NHTSA and local and state traffic laws.

The House Energy & Commerce committee last Thursday advanced legislation on a 54-0 vote that would begin the process of changing regulations to allow cars and trucks that operate without human drivers. Similar legislation is being developed in the Senate with rare bipartisan support, an effort supported by automakers such as Ford Motor Co. and Tesla Inc. as well as technology firms Alphabet Inc., Lyft Inc. and others that are developing the vehicles.

The more high priority things that consume Congress, the less likely this is to get through. And the House only has 51 days left in session between now (today included) and 1 January. Looking at the House website, it doesn't appear this will get a floor vote before they go on recess on Friday, especially since there is fighting about what budget bills should be voted on before then.  The Senate has 74 (if they continue with a delayed recess, otherwise 64) days left in session. And during that time, they have to tackle health care, tax reform, a bipartisan budget agreement to skirt BCA 2011 caps, an FY18 budget resolution, a CR for the first few weeks of FY18, raising the debt ceiling, and maybe infrastructure, all topped by whatever sideshow they have to contend with from a WH that struggles to stay on message.

I think legislation will no doubt increase the exemption number, but under the 100,000. In addition  the legislation may also require states to adopt the proper legislation to handle autonomous vehicles on their roads.

Not necessarily an influencing factor for the decision by lawmakers, but this is one of the effects of increased self-driving cars: http://www.insurancejournal.com/news/national/2017/05/19/451621.htm. Separately, the question of the President signing any legislation is always a tricky one. While this might slide by without much debate, it could also get sidelined as the Congress and WH focus on trying to get a major legislative win. This apparently did get voted out of Committee, if I'm reading the right bill (http://docs.house.gov/meetings/IF/IF17/20170719/106309/BILLS-115pih-HighlyAutomatedVehicleTesti-U2.pdf). However, whether it even gets a floor vote is dependent on the priorities of House leadership. There's no scheduled floor vote as far as I can tell, but the House website is lacking in comparison to the Senate's. With a week left before recess, I'd be surprised if it gets a floor vote looking at the other legislative items on the docket. After that, the House needs to pass a budget resolution, a bipartisan budget agreement to raise BCA caps to avoid sequestration, a debt ceiling raise, maybe health care reform (although very unlikely), and tax reform.
I say no mainly due to the time frame and that autonomous vehicles could be seen as a job killer.

This is precisely the sort of issue that gets dealt with incrementally in practically every country--so up some this year and some more two years from now, and so on.  There are many numbers between 2,500 and 100,000 and for most legislators the indifference zone is pretty wide.  Even the current crop of clowns should be able to get this sorted.    On further reflection, that last sentence seems wildly optimistic, but I'll chance it anyway.

The major factor in self driving vehicles is the trucking industry and significant job losses in the not so distant future.  President Trump is very familiar with the AFL-CIO from real estate development in NY and NJ and I strongly believe the AFL-CIO will effectively lobby to push back increases in allowances of self driving vehicles.  Trucking company owners are probably drooling at the thought of these increases, but will likely have to wait some time for the increases to take place.  As a side note, President Trump and his children may have personally lowered Wharton's MBA ranking.

Highly unlikely. In this list of manufacturers pursuing autonomous vehicle technology (https://www.cbinsights.com/research/autonomous-driverless-vehicles-corporations-list/) you'll notice Ford and GM. Ford is aiming for 2021 to roll out "highly autonomous" vehicles. GM is closer, partnering with Lyft to test autonomous Chevrolet Bolts in 2018. However, it doesn't appear that GM has a fleet of autonomous vehicles ready to roll out, save for the Cadillac CT6 ($53K and up). I focus on Ford and GM, as they have deep roots in American manufacturing, and subsequently American political lobbying. If legislation were to pass opening exemptions drastically, these two "staples" of American manufacturing jobs would be significantly behind the competition. I anticipate they'll lobby behind the scenes (and maybe publicly) to stop this legislation until they're on a more even playing field, if not with a leg up on the competition. And that's leaving out the GOP's legislative woes.
